hr.p: USD 383 schools will continue with the scheduled pick up for devices (AMS, EMS, MHSE & MHSW) on March 30 and 31 and student belongings and packets (elementary schools) on March 31 and April 1. Please abide by all safety requirements.
All of our plans have been approved by the Riley County Health Department.

Like many I have spoken to this past week, I was saddened by the March 17 announcement that school buildings would be closed for the remainder of this school year. I agreed with the reasoning behind the closure and applauded Governor Kelly for the bold move to lessen COVID-19âs impact on Kansas, yet I also felt a sense of loss over the many opportunities that might not occur for students during the Spring of 2020 - what about school performances? recognition ceremonies? competitive events? Commencement? Then came the realization that students and families will need broad support from USD 383 like perhaps never before - not just academically, but with needs such as meals, communication, physical and mental wellness, basic supplies, transportation, and referral assistance to a variety of community agencies.

Fortunately, the Executive Order that closed school buildings on March 17 also had provisions for continuation of learning and other services provided by public school systems. During this past week, USD 383 staff have worked diligently, creatively and cooperatively to develop a Continuous Learning Plan that allows us to resume services to students and families on Wednesday, April 1. Details of the plan will be revealed in the near future; however, this letter provides information about the coming week that is most significant for USD 383 families:

ul.li: USD 383âs Continuous Learning Plan will begin with students and families on April 1, 2020. To prepare for this implementation, you will receive general messages from the school district and one or more school principals during the coming week.

You will also be contacted directly by school employees. Please make every effort to communicate with these individuals, as their intent is to find out if there are specific ways USD 383 can help you and your family with the challenges of these unprecedented times. More specifically, staff will be contacting every family to conduct aÂ Family Wellness Check-In. The Check-In consists of a small number of questions (7-12 depending on family circumstances) that will help us design and implement a service delivery plan that takes into consideration factors such as meals, physical health, emotional well-being, technology, exceptionalities, language needs and other services.

Each school has developed a process for distribution of personal belongings and continuous learning instructional materials that complies with the order banning public gatherings of more than 10 people in Riley County. Upcoming communication from principals and through the Family Wellness Check-InÂ will provide more about this process.Â

hr.p: Thank you to everyone who completed surveyâs from USD 383 during this past week. Your extraordinary response rate helped us more quickly mobilize resources for our Continuous Learning Plan. I also want to thank the many people who have so generously offered their assistance. As is so often the case in our amazing community, offers to help were swift and numerous - fueling our long-term desire to become stronger, better and more compassionate from what is learned through our community-wide response to COVID-19.

In closing, I want to quote Board President Karla Hagemeister, who asks us to âPlease be kind to each other and please remember to take care of yourself. Leave room for mistakes and course corrections...and hand out grace like it's candy.â

Superintendent Dr. Marvin Wade
Manhattan-Ogden USD 383

On March 17, 2020, Governor Laura Kelly announced that all school facilities will be closed the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. This will place tremendous hardship on our families and staff, and impact the social and emotional well-being of our students.
We have been working on contingency plans since mid-March, including how we can meet the continuous learning needs of our students and provide breakfast and lunch for our students. Our staff and board of education are also working on other critical issues, such as what this means for our seniors, how this will affect next school year and what impact this will have on our employees. We will provide updates on these issues as soon as the information is available.
We understand the financial impact a school closure may have on our staff members. We are committed to working together as a community to support one another throughout these unprecedented times, and communications will remain a top priority.
As a reminder, this school closure is in response to the current public health crisis. The focus should remain on preventing the spread the coronavirus, or COVID-19 as it is also referred to.
Please be mindful of the following:
â¢ Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
â¢ Cover your nose and mouth when coughing and sneezing (cough/sneeze into your sleeve or a tissue).
â¢ Please keep sick children at home.
â¢ Avoid close contact with anyone with cold or flu-like symptoms.
Follow additional guidance from these sources:
â¢ National Center for Disease Control (CDC)
â¢ Kansas Department of Health and Environment
â¢ Riley County Health Department
Thank you for your patience and grace as we continue to work through this ever-changing situation.
Please continue to check our social media and our website for updates.
